ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A proposal offered for acceptance or rejection.: Existing in fact; real. (from American Heritage Dictionary): (ma-LIG-nant) Cancerous; a growth with a tendency to invade and destroy nearby tissue and spread to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A proposal offered for acceptance or rejection.
Existing in fact; real.
Refers to abnormal cell activity manifested by decreased control over growth and function, causing tumor growth or spread into surrounding tissue and adverse effects to the host.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

PermissibleValues.value: Biopsy should be considered - Cytologic analysis

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cytology; the branch of biology that studies the structure and function of cells.

Concepts.definition: The light microscopic study of normal and abnormal cells in fine needle aspirates (FNAs), body cavity fluids, and smears.

PermissibleValues.value: Biopsy should be considered - Needle localization and biopsy

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.: An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.: A device part with a long, slender, pointed shape.: (LO-kal-ih-ZAY-shun) The process of determining or marking the location or site of a lesion or disease. May also refer to the process of keeping a lesion or disease in a specific location or site.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.
An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.
A device part with a long, slender, pointed shape.
The process of determining or marking the location or site of a lesion or disease.

PermissibleValues.value: Biopsy should be considered - Histology using core biopsy

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having little (physical) length or seeming to be limited in (temporal) duration.: The period of time or the distance separating two instances, events, or occurrences.: The process by which information about the health status of an individual is obtained after a study has officially closed.

Concepts.definition: Having little (physical) length or seeming to be limited in (temporal) duration.
The period of time or the distance separating two instances, events, or occurrences.

The process by which information about the health status of an individual is obtained after a study has officially closed; an activity that continues something that has already begun or that repeats something that has already been done.

PermissibleValues.value: Additional imaging - Old films for comparison

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The examination of two or more people or things in order to detect similarities and differences.: A photographic material designed to capture an image upon exposure to electromagnetic radiation.

Concepts.definition: The examination of two or more people or things in order to detect similarities and differences.
A photographic material designed to capture an image upon exposure to electromagnetic radiation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: High frequency sound, generally with a frequency greater than 20,000 Hz.

Concepts.definition: High frequency sound, generally with a frequency greater than 20,000 Hz.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Imaging examination of the breast by means of x-rays.

Concepts.definition: A type of radiography used specifically to examine breast tissue. The procedure utilizes a low-dose of x-rays or radiation to generate an image. A mammography exam or mammogram, is used as a screening tool to detect early breast cancer in women experiencing no symptoms and to detect and diagnose breast disease.
